john_test_smith.chief_complaint: Persistent cough and fever for 5 days
john_test_smith.family_history: Father had heart disease, mother has diabetes
john_test_smith.conversation_summary: Patient reports 5-day history of persistent dry cough with fever ranging 101-102°F. Experiences fatigue and mild chest tightness. Currently manages diabetes and hypertension with medications. Takes medications as prescribed. No known allergies.
john_test_smith.ai_assessment: Patient should schedule in-person appointment within 24-48 hours. Symptoms suggest possible respiratory infection. If difficulty breathing or chest pain worsens, seek immediate care.

sarah_jones.conversation_summary: Patient would like to schedule annual physical exam. No current health concerns. Reports feeling well.
sarah_jones.ai_assessment: Patient can schedule routine physical exam appointment. No urgent concerns noted.

jordan_carter.chief_complaint: Cough for ~3 weeks, worse at night.

history.hpi: 58-year-old man with 3-week predominantly dry cough worse at night and when supine; occasional clear morning sputum; mild exertional dyspnea on stairs; one night of low-grade fever. Increased nocturnal heartburn, especially after late meals. Began lisinopril ~2 months ago; cough started a few weeks later. Recent flight from Austin; grandson with URI. Tea and lozenges help.
medications_prior_to_visit: lisinopril 10 mg PO QD (started ~2 months ago)

social_history.home_support: Lives with spouse; spouse available to help at home

exam.lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally; no wheezes/crackles
exam.cardiac: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs

medication_changes.start: benzonatate 100 mg PO TID PRN cough (max 200 mg TID)
albuterol HFA 2 puffs q6h PRN wheeze/tightness
famotidine 20 mg PO BID x 2–4 weeks

conditional_orders: Chest X-ray if cough persists > 2 weeks after stopping ACE inhibitor or if new fever, chest pain, hemoptysis, or worsening dyspnea
education: Avoid late meals; limit caffeine/alcohol at night
plan.shared_decision_making: Patient agrees to ACEi→ARB switch and to defer immediate CXR unless persistent symptoms.

impact_on_function.work: Cough interrupts phone calls and presentations; worse with prolonged speaking at sales job.
impact_on_function.sleep: Nocturnal cough wakes patient when supine.

exposures.travel: Commercial flight from Austin 3 weeks prior to visit
sick_contacts: Grandson with cold two weeks prior

medication_side_effects_and_concerns.patient_concerns: Open to switching medications to resolve cough
medication_side_effects_and_concerns.adherence_prior: Reports taking metformin and lisinopril as prescribed

adherence_and_acceptance.notes: Agreed to ARB switch, PRN meds, GERD measures, and follow-ups.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Hi Jordan, what brings you in today?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I’ve had a cough for about three weeks. It’s worse at night and when I talk a lot.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any fever, shortness of breath, chest pain, or coughing up blood?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No blood. I sometimes feel a little short of breath walking up stairs, but no chest pain. I had one night of a low-grade fever last week, like ninety-nine-ish.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Is the cough dry or with phlegm? Any color?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Mostly dry. Occasionally a little clear mucus in the morning.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any sick contacts or recent travel?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: My grandson had a cold two weeks ago. I flew back from Austin three weeks ago.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: What makes it better or worse?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Lying down makes it worse. Hot tea helps. I tried some over-the-counter cough drops.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Do you get heartburn or a sour taste at night?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, more heartburn lately, especially if I eat late.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: You’re on metformin 1000 mg twice daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily, correct?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes. I started lisinopril about two months ago.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Some people get a dry cough from lisinopril. Did your cough start after you began it?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I think the cough started a few weeks after I began the lisinopril. I didn’t connect the dots.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any history of asthma, allergies, or smoking?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No asthma and I don’t smoke. I only get seasonal allergies in the spring.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: How is home—do you have support if you feel worse?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I live with my wife. She can help out if needed.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any swelling in your legs, unintentional weight loss, or night sweats?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: None of those.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: How is your diabetes control? Any home glucose readings?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Fasting numbers are around 130 to 150. I haven’t been walking as much since traveling.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I’ll check your vitals and listen to your lungs.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Your lungs sound clear, oxygen is good. This is most likely a subacute cough—post-viral, reflux-related, or from lisinopril.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: What should we do?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Let’s stop lisinopril and switch to losartan. I’ll prescribe benzonatate for cough and an albuterol inhaler if you feel tightness. Try elevating the head of your bed and avoid late meals. If it doesn’t improve, we’ll get a chest X-ray.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Sounds good to me.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any concerns about medications or side effects?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No, I just want this cough gone. I’m fine switching meds.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Is the cough affecting work or sleep?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes—on sales calls it makes me pause a lot, and at night it wakes me when I lie flat.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I’ll also order labs today for diabetes and to monitor the new blood pressure medicine. We’ll schedule a follow-up in two weeks. If you get a high fever, chest pain, or cough up blood, call immediately.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Will do. Thanks, doctor.

rebecca_martinez.chief_complaint: Right knee pain and swelling for 2 weeks.

history.hpi: 52-year-old woman with 2-week history of progressive right knee pain and swelling; acute onset after stepping awkwardly while gardening. Pain is anterior and medial, worse with stairs, squatting, and prolonged standing; improved with rest and ice. No locking or giving way. Mild morning stiffness that improves with activity. No trauma or prior knee injury; has osteoarthritis in left knee (diagnosed 3 years ago). Recently increased gardening and yard work intensity.
medications_prior_to_visit: ibuprofen 400 mg PO PRN pain (several times weekly)

social_history.home_support: Lives with spouse and adult daughter; supportive family

exam.general: Alert, appears comfortable at rest; pain with movement
exam.extremities: Right knee: moderate effusion, warmth, and tenderness over medial joint line; positive McMurray's test; no ligamentous laxity; full ROM painful; left knee: chronic changes without acute swelling; bilateral feet/ankles unremarkable

medication_changes.start: meloxicam 15 mg PO QD x 2 weeks then reassess
cyclobenzaprine 5 mg PO QHS PRN muscle tightness

conditional_orders: Orthopedic surgery referral if MRI shows significant meniscal tear or ligamentous injury
education: RICE protocol: rest, ice (15 min q4-6h), compression, elevation
Activity modification: avoid stairs/squatting for 1 week; resume gradually
Physical therapy referral for strengthening and ROM
Return precautions: worsening swelling, signs of infection, or persistent locked knee

follow_up.purpose: review imaging, reassess need for surgery
assess response to anti-inflammatory therapy and PT

plan.shared_decision_making: Patient agrees to conservative management with imaging and PT first; open to surgery if imaging reveals significant tear and conservative measures fail.

impact_on_function.work: Unable to do fieldwork or site visits; limited to office design work temporarily.
impact_on_function.activities: Cannot hike, garden, or go up stairs without significant pain; sleep mildly disrupted by discomfort when turning.
impact_on_function.daily_living: Difficulty with household chores; moving around home requires caution and slow pace.

self_care_and_remedies.perceived_benefit: Temporary relief with ice and rest; pain returns with activity

exposures.recent_activities: Increased gardening and yard work over past month; stepped awkwardly while carrying mulch
exposures.mechanical_factors: Repetitive squatting and kneeling for landscaping work

medication_side_effects_and_concerns.patient_concerns: Concerned about frequent ibuprofen use; prefers to avoid long-term NSAIDs; interested in physical therapy
medication_side_effects_and_concerns.adherence_prior: Adherent with chronic meds; uses NSAIDs as needed without tracking frequency

adherence_and_acceptance.notes: Patient receptive to conservative approach with PT; willing to try meloxicam for limited duration; interested in preventive strategies.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Hi Rebecca, I see you're having some right knee trouble. Tell me what happened.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yeah, about two weeks ago I twisted my knee while gardening. I stepped wrong carrying a heavy mulch bag. It's been swollen and painful ever since.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Was there a popping sound or sensation at the time?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: I didn't hear anything pop, but it did hurt sharply in that moment. The pain settled into a dull ache, but the swelling got worse over the next few days.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Have you had any episodes of your knee giving way or locking?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No locking or giving way, thank goodness. Just pain and swelling.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any prior knee injuries or problems?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: My left knee has arthritis—I was diagnosed a few years ago. But the right knee was fine until this.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: What makes the pain better or worse?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Resting and ice help a lot. But stairs, squatting, and even standing for long periods makes it worse. I've basically been avoiding my landscaping work.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any redness, warmth, or signs of infection in the knee?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: It's a bit warm and red around the swelling, but I don't think it's infected. It doesn't feel like a fever or anything.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Are you on any regular medications?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, lisinopril for blood pressure and atorvastatin for cholesterol. I also take ibuprofen fairly often for aches—maybe several times a week, especially when I'm gardening a lot.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I'm going to examine your knee now and check your range of motion.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I can feel the swelling and some tenderness along the inside of your knee joint. Your McMurray's test is positive, which suggests possible meniscal involvement, but I need imaging to be sure.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Does that mean I need surgery?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Let's see what the MRI shows first. Many meniscal issues respond well to conservative treatment—rest, anti-inflammatory medication, and physical therapy. If imaging shows a significant tear and conservative measures don't help, then we'd consider other options.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: That sounds reasonable. I'd prefer to avoid surgery if possible.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I'll order an MRI. For now, follow RICE—rest, ice every 4 to 6 hours for 15 minutes, compression, and elevation. Avoid stairs and squatting for about a week. I'll start you on meloxicam, an anti-inflammatory, to help reduce the swelling.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: How long do I need to take the meloxicam?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: I'd suggest about 2 weeks, then we reassess. If you're feeling better, we can taper it down. I'm also going to refer you to physical therapy—that will be crucial for regaining strength and range of motion.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay, and what about my work? I do landscaping, so I'm on my feet a lot.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: You'll need to limit fieldwork for at least a week or two. Focus on office-based design work if possible. As you improve, you can gradually return to more activity. PT will help guide that.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: All right. What if the MRI shows something serious?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: We'll discuss all options then, including surgical consultation if needed. But let's take this step by step. I'll call you once I have the MRI results—should be within a few days.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Thanks, doctor. I appreciate the thorough approach.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: You're welcome. Keep that knee elevated and iced. We'll be in touch soon.

emily_chen.chief_complaint: Fever and chills for 2 weeks, occurring in cycles.

history.hpi: 34-year-old woman presenting with 2-week history of high fever (101–104°F) occurring in cycles every 48-72 hours, accompanied by severe chills, profuse diaphoresis, and muscle/joint pain. Fever pattern is remittent. Patient reports severe fatigue, malaise, and mild abdominal discomfort. Returned from 3-week trip to Tanzania 2 weeks ago (visited Dar es Salaam and rural areas); no antimalarial prophylaxis taken. No respiratory symptoms, no diarrhea. Denies recent sick contacts. Reports insect bites during travel, particularly mosquitoes at dawn/dusk. No medical interventions or over-the-counter medications taken; symptoms began gradually after return.

exam.general: Alert but appearing ill; currently febrile and diaphoretic
exam.heent: Icteric sclera noted; no lymphadenopathy; oropharynx clear
exam.cardiac: Tachycardic at 102 bpm, regular rhythm, no murmurs
exam.abdomen: Soft, mildly tender in RUQ; hepatosplenomegaly noted (liver edge 2 cm below costal margin, spleen palpable at costal margin)
exam.extremities: No edema; no rash; petechiae absent
exam.neuro: Alert and oriented; normal motor and sensory exam

assessment.problem: Fever of unknown origin with cyclic pattern
likely_etiologies: Malaria (P. falciparum, P. vivax, P. ovale, or P. malariae given 48-72 hour fever cycle and travel to endemic region)
Dengue fever (travel history, fever pattern, malaise)
Typhoid fever (gradual onset, malaise, abdominal tenderness, hepatosplenomegaly)
Q fever or other zoonotic infection
assessment.concern: Cyclic fever after travel to malaria-endemic area is highly concerning for malaria; hepatosplenomegaly supports tropical infection

assessment.context: Consistent with malaria, dengue, typhoid, or tuberculosis
Suggests hemolysis or liver involvement; concerning for severe malaria with hemolytic anemia

diagnostic_workup: Thick and thin blood smears for malaria parasites (URGENT - repeat x3 if initial negative)
Rapid diagnostic test (RDT) for malaria antigens (P. falciparum, P. vivax)
Complete blood count with differential (assess for anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis)
Liver function tests (AST, ALT, bilirubin, albumin)
Renal function (creatinine, BUN) to assess for acute kidney injury
Blood cultures x2 (rule out bacteremia, endocarditis, typhoid)
Typhoid serology and blood culture on selective media
empiric_treatment: Hold antimalarials pending diagnostic confirmation; patient counseled about wait-and-see approach
Supportive care: acetaminophen for fever/myalgias; encourage fluid intake
Monitor closely for warning signs of severe malaria: altered mental status, seizures, severe anemia, renal failure
orders_today: STAT: CBC with differential, comprehensive metabolic panel, LFTs
education: Explained cyclic fever pattern and malaria risk after travel
Discussed importance of rapid diagnosis given travel history
Return precautions: severe headache, confusion, difficulty breathing, severe abdominal pain, dark urine, or seizures → ER immediately

follow_up.purpose: Discuss diagnostic findings and start treatment if malaria confirmed
Repeat blood smears if initial negative and fever persists; reassess treatment response

plan.shared_decision_making: Patient understands need for urgent labs to identify cause. Agreed not to start empiric antimalarials until confirmation given diagnostic uncertainty. Will follow up emergently if symptoms worsen.

impact_on_function.work: Unable to work; too ill; called in sick to photography assignments
impact_on_function.activities: Confined to bed during fever episodes; significant malaise between cycles
impact_on_function.daily_living: Severe fatigue making basic self-care difficult

otc_used: Minimal; used acetaminophen once but avoided others

exposures.travel: 3-week trip to Tanzania (Dar es Salaam, rural Morogoro region) 2 weeks ago
exposures.mosquito_exposure: Significant exposure to mosquitoes, particularly at dawn/dusk in rural areas; no mosquito net used consistently
exposures.prophylaxis: No antimalarial prophylaxis taken before or during trip
exposures.food_water: Ate local food and drinks; water source varied (some from tap, some bottled)

adherence_and_acceptance.notes: Patient very receptive to workup; anxious about diagnosis given travel history; understands urgency

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Hi Emily, I see you've been having fevers for about 2 weeks. Tell me what's been going on.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Yes, it started right after I got back from Tanzania. I was there for 3 weeks, traveling around, taking photos. At first I thought it was jet lag, but then the fever started and it just won't stop.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Is the fever constant, or does it come and go?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: It comes and goes. Every couple of days I get this incredibly high fever—like 103, 104—and I get these violent chills and start sweating through my clothes. Then after a few hours it breaks and I feel almost normal for a while. But then it comes back.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any other symptoms with the fevers?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: My muscles and joints ache so badly. My whole body hurts. And I'm exhausted—like, I can barely get out of bed. My stomach's been bothering me a bit too, kind of achy in the upper right area.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any cough, sore throat, or difficulty breathing?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No, nothing like that. Just the fever, chills, body aches, and this overwhelming tiredness.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Where exactly did you travel in Tanzania?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Mainly around Dar es Salaam for the first week, then I went inland to Morogoro region to photograph wildlife and landscapes. Smaller towns, rural areas. I was there when mosquitoes are most active—dawn and dusk.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Did you take any antimalarial medications?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No, I didn't. I didn't think to get them before the trip, and by the time I realized I should have, I was already going. I did get bitten by mosquitoes a lot, especially in the evenings. I didn't always have a mosquito net.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Any yellow discoloration to your skin or eyes that you've noticed?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Actually, now that you mention it, my mom said my eyes looked a bit yellow yesterday. I thought maybe I was just tired.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Have you had any rash, spots, or bleeding?

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: No rash, no bleeding. Just feeling really sick.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Let me examine you and check some things. I'm going to feel your belly.

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Emily, I can feel your liver and spleen are enlarged, and your eyes do appear icteric—yellowish. Given your travel to Tanzania, the cyclic fever pattern, and these findings, we need to rule out malaria and other tropical infections urgently.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Malaria? Oh my god. Is that serious?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Malaria can be serious if not treated, which is why we need to diagnose it quickly. But many cases respond very well to treatment. I'm going to order blood tests right away—blood smears to look for the malaria parasite under the microscope, and other tests to help us understand what's going on.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: How quickly will we know?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: The blood smear can be done urgently, often within hours. We should have preliminary results today. If the first test is negative but your fever continues, we'll repeat it—sometimes the parasite can be hard to find on the first try.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: And if it is malaria, what then?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: We have very effective antimalarial medications. The type of medication depends on which type of malaria parasite you have, so the blood smear will help us know. Once we confirm the diagnosis, we'll start treatment, and most people recover fully.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Okay. I'm scared, but I'm glad I came in. What do I do in the meantime?

transcript.speaker: Provider
transcript.text: Rest, drink plenty of fluids, and take acetaminophen for the fever and body aches. If you develop confusion, severe headache, difficulty breathing, or very dark urine, go to the ER immediately. We'll call you as soon as the results are back.

transcript.speaker: Patient
transcript.text: Thank you, doctor.
